stream_context.summary: Kaze models a new "folded-paper" Thwomp with googly eyes, then imports and debugs Biobak’s latest Course 1 overhaul: fixing material flags, lighting, draw-order, and performance so the level renders correctly on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: A new Thwomp enemy is being built from a folded cardboard cube with movable googly eyes and cardboard eyebrows to match the papercraft aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I want this to look like a Thwomp. It's very important to me.

development_findings.summary: Enemy poly budget is kept around 160–300 triangles; the new Thwomp is 164, within Kaze’s comfort zone for N64 performance.
Thwomp audio/FX plan: rattling impact sound (as if filled with objects), snow-like footstep SFX instead of stone, and eye-bounce animation on attack.
Kaze rejects LOD models for now, believing Fast64 lacks efficient branch culling and that static optimization is preferable.
development_findings.quote: I'm not really a believer in lots. I think lots are very overrated with the current setup.

development_findings.summary: Course 1 received a major visual pass from Biobak: new lighting, extra geometry depth, carrot-filled caves, vine-wrapped slide, updated sky, red castle roofs, and retro pipe area with flagpole.

Kaze spent the stream hunting down rendering bugs introduced by incorrect material settings (missing Z-buffer, wrong cycle type, disabled smooth shading, point filtering, etc.) and re-exported the level.
development_findings.quote: How did any of this happen? I have no idea, Biobak.

development_findings.summary: Retro sub-area now uses camera-only lighting to mimic 8-bit aesthetics; global lights removed except minimal ambient.
Boss arena plan change: instead of the King Goomba treadmill effect, boulders will pursue Mario while the king moves independently for better readability.
Overall project status: 15 courses planned; Course 14 is in progress, Course 15 is ~50 % complete; only three new actors remain to be made, potentially finishing soon.
Plot is being reconsidered: original ‘Bowser enslaves Yoshis’ storyline deemed too grim; Kaze seeks a lighter threat to motivate gameplay.

context_findings.summary: Kaze juggles development with personal life; had to leave early for Thanksgiving dinner, limiting the session to one hour.
He enjoys iterative perfectionism on Course 1 but claims it’s still <10 % of total dev time despite countless passes.
context_findings.quote: Development time spent on course one is probably like seven percent.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values sandbox worlds where stars are found through embedded linear or puzzle challenges, aiming for more ‘meat’ per star than vanilla SM64.
He is cautious about over-using new graphical effects after initial excitement, preferring restrained implementation.
context_findings.quote: You’re very prone to overdo it and I probably overdid it the first time I used it.

biobak.summary: Delivered ‘course 1 update.zip’ featuring extensive geometry, texture, and lighting revisions plus performance optimizations that surprisingly reduced triangles by ten compared to the previous build.
Requested feedback on origami Thwomp design and committed to finish the Thwomp rework and level tweaks possibly within the day.

zeina.summary: Offered to recreate missing red Goomba banners for the boss castle if needed.

key_stories.title: Making a Papercraft Thwomp
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries to transform a classic stone Thwomp into a papercraft enemy. He experiments with folding planes, origami references, cardboard textures, and movable googly eyes while retaining the Thwomp’s iconic angry face.
key_stories.challenge: Translating a stone monster into convincing paper without losing recognizability.
key_stories.process: Iterated on folds, adjusted UVs, debated materials (duct tape vs cardboard), enlarged eyes, and coded eye physics.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on a folded-cube body with cardboard eyebrows and animated googly eyes; implementation of sounds and collisions still pending.
key_stories.key_quote: I want this to look like a Thwomp. I love the Thwomp.

key_stories.title: Course 1: The Perpetual Rework
key_stories.summary: Biobak shipped another big Course 1 overhaul. Kaze imported it live, discovering numerous render issues from misplaced material flags and lighting. Together they debugged and noted further tweaks.
key_stories.challenge: Ensuring the flagship level looks perfect and runs on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Biobak remodeled assets; Kaze fixed Z-buffer, cycle types, shading, and lighting; they documented future tasks (sky draw order, sun flare, collision, boss changes).
key_stories.outcome: Level now renders correctly at ~50 FPS; further adjustments queued for next stream.
key_stories.key_quote: Time for my weekly Course 1 rework.

open_questions.topic: Final enemy behavior and SFX for the papercraft Thwomp
open_questions.context: Eyes bounce and rattling impact were discussed, but attack patterns, damage logic, and full sound design are undecided.
questions: What specific behaviors will differentiate the papercraft Thwomp from the vanilla version?
How will the googly-eye physics be implemented on N64 hardware?
What sound library or recording process will you use to achieve the ‘rattling cardboard’ effect?

open_questions.context: Despite many passes, the level keeps changing; Kaze downplays the time but still calls for more tweaks.
questions: What will signal that Course 1 is finally ‘locked’?
How do you balance polish on Course 1 against progress on later worlds?
Has constant reworking affected team morale or schedules?

open_questions.context: Kaze scrapped the Bowser-enslaves-Yoshis plot but hasn’t settled on an alternative.
questions: What narrative tone are you aiming for now?
How will the new story justify the papercraft aesthetic and Yoshi’s Island setting?
Who participates in story decisions, and how do you vet ideas for appropriateness?

open_questions.context: Numerous manual fixes were required due to Fast64 version mismatches and misunderstood flags.
questions: What is your standard workflow for ensuring materials are N64-safe?
Could a shared style guide or tool automation reduce these errors?
How do you test assets on real hardware versus emulators?

open_questions.context: Kaze dismisses LODs as ‘overrated’ with current tooling.
questions: What frame-rate/resolution targets do you set for each level?
Under what conditions would you revisit LOD usage?
How do you prioritize visual fidelity versus hardware limits?
